definition[0]: to make something into the shape of a tube or ball, or to become this shape
example[0]: Painters arrived and rolled up the carpet.
example[1]: Many animals roll up into a ball for warmth.
definition[1]: to turn the ends of your sleeves or trouser legs over several times so that they are shorter
definition[2]: to start doing a job even though it is difficult or you do not want to do it
example[2]: It’s time to roll up our sleeves and get some work done on the basics.
definition[3]: to close the window of a car
definition[4]: to arrive somewhere, especially late or when you were not expected
example[3]: Max rolled up just after 9 o'clock.
definition[5]: used to call people to come and watch or buy things at a circus or fair
definition[6]: a cigarette that you make yourself
definition[7]: if a company or financial institution rolls up the regular payments that would normally be made on an investment, it adds them to the value of the investment and pays them out when the investment MATUREs (=reaches the end of its life)
example[4]: The interest is rolled up over the life of the security and paid out when it is redeemed.
